We refer to basic statistical principles for help. Positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a positive test result reflects the true presence of the disease in the tested population. It is affected by prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity. In a low-prevalence population, false positives can still be common even with high specificity. Thus, an increase in prevalence will increase PPV, while an increase in incidence or a decrease in incidence will not affect PPV. Lowering the threshold concentration for a positive test will increase sensitivity and may increase the number of true positives, but it will also increase the number of false positives, thus decreasing PPV.
